nexttext:
One can easily check that ${\mathcal{P}}^*=\{\{1,2\},\{3\},\{4\}\}$, ${I(X_{\mathcal{M}})}=1.5$ and $R_{{\text{CO}}}=3.5$. Solving the linear program in Theorem~\ref{th:ub}, we see that the optimal fractional packing ${\mathbf{x}}^*$ is given by ${\mathbf{x}}^*(\{1,2\})=1.5$ and ${\mathbf{x}}^*(e)={\mathbf{w}}(e)$ for all $e\neq\{1,2\}$. Thus, Theorem~\ref{th:ub} gives the upper bound $R_{{\text{SK}}}\leq 3<R_{{\text{CO}}}$.

It is not difficult to check that no integer-valued ${\mathbf{x}}\neq{\mathbf{w}}$ is possible without decreasing the SK capacity. Thus even if ${\mathbf{w}}$ is integer-valued, removing a hyperedge by an integer amount or completely need not be optimal, and fractional removal is a better thing to do. 
\end{example}

We now turn our attention to evaluating the upper bound in Theorem~\ref{th:ub}. Evaluating the upper bound in Theorem~\ref{th:ub} requires the knowledge of ${I(X_{\mathcal{M}})}$, which in turn can be calculated in strongly polynomial time as shown in \cite{Chan14}. Knowing ${I(X_{\mathcal{M}})}$, the upper bound in Theorem~\ref{th:ub} can be computed in polynomial time. This is because the separation oracle for the constraints in \eqref{gub:2}, i.e., $\sum_{i\in B}r_i\geq \sum_{e\in{\mathcal{E}}: e\subseteq B}{\mathbf{x}}(e)=H(X^{\mathbf{x}}_B|X^{\mathbf{x}}_{B^c})$, for all $B\subsetneq{\mathcal{M}}$, is but an instance of a submodular function minimization given by $\min_{B\subsetneq{\mathcal{M}}}\biggl\{\sum_{i\in B}r_i-H(X^{\mathbf{x}}_B|X^{\mathbf{x}}_{B^c})\biggr\}\geq0$. The fact that submodular function minimization can be carried out in polynomial time (see Theorem~45.1 of \cite{Schrijver}), implies that the upper bound in Theorem~\ref{th:ub} can also be computed in polynomial time (see Theorem~5.10 of \cite{Schrijver}).

It turns out that for the special case of graphical models, i.e., when ${\mathcal{E}}$ consists only of sets of size 2, the upper bound in Theorem~\ref{th:ub} reduces to a very simple expression.

\begin{theorem}\label{th:PIN}
For a source $X_{\mathcal{M}}$ defined on a weighted graph ${\mathcal{G}}=({\mathcal{M}},{\mathbf{w}})$ we have

where \eqref{cmi0} and \eqref{cmi1} follow from the fact that ${\textsf{L}}$ is a function of $X_{{\mathcal{M}}}^n$; \eqref{cmi2} follows from the fact that $H(X_{{\mathcal{M}}}^n)=n\sum_{e\in{\mathcal{E}}}{\mathbf{w}}(e)$ and $\sum_{A\in{\mathcal{P}}^*}H(X_A^n)=n\biggl[\sum_{e\in{\mathcal{E}}}{\mathbf{w}}(e)+\sum_{e\in{\mathcal{E}}_{{\mathcal{P}}^*}}{\mathbf{w}}(e)\biggr]$; and \eqref{cmi3} is due to Lemma~\ref{lem:mi}.

Now, consider $\textsf{L}$ to be any ${\text{CI}}_W$ so that for any $\epsilon > 0$, we have $\frac{1}{n}I(X_{\mathcal{M}}^n | \textsf{L}) < \frac{\epsilon}{(|{\mathcal{P}}^*|-1)}$ for all sufficiently large $n$. The bound in \eqref{cmi3} thus yields $\frac{1}{n}H({\textsf{L}})> \sum_{e\in{\mathcal{E}}_{{\mathcal{P}}^*}}{\mathbf{w}}(e)-\epsilon$ for all sufficiently large $n$. Hence, it follows that ${\text{CI}}_W(X_{{\mathcal{M}}}) \ge \sum_{e\in{\mathcal{E}}_{{\mathcal{P}}^*}}{\mathbf{w}}(e)$. Therefore, we obtain $CI_W(X_{{\mathcal{M}}})=\sum_{e\in{\mathcal{E}}_{{\mathcal{P}}^*}}{\mathbf{w}}(e)$.
\end{IEEEproof} 

We now prove Theorem~\ref{th:lb}.

\begin{IEEEproof}[Proof of Theorem~\ref{th:lb}]
For the source $X_{{\mathcal{M}}}$ we have
text:
\begin{align}
I(X_{\mathcal{M}}^n | \textsf{L}) 
   & = \frac{1}{|{\mathcal{P}}^*|-1}\biggl[\sum_{A\in{\mathcal{P}}^*}H(X_A^n|{\textsf{L}})-H(X_{{\mathcal{M}}}^n|{\textsf{L}})\biggr]\notag\\
   & = \frac{1}{|{\mathcal{P}}^*|-1}\biggl[\sum_{A\in{\mathcal{P}}^*}\left(H(X_A^n,{\textsf{L}})-H({\textsf{L}})\right)\notag\\
   &\hspace{2cm}-H(X_{{\mathcal{M}}}^n,{\textsf{L}})+H({\textsf{L}})\biggr]\notag\\
   & = H(X_{{\mathcal{M}}}^n,{\textsf{L}})-H({\textsf{L}})\notag\\
   &\hspace{0.5cm}+\frac{1}{|{\mathcal{P}}^*|-1}\biggl[\sum_{A\in{\mathcal{P}}^*}\left(H(X_A^n,{\textsf{L}})-H(X_{{\mathcal{M}}}^n,{\textsf{L}})\right)\biggr]\notag\\
   & = H(X_{{\mathcal{M}}}^n)-H({\textsf{L}})-\frac{1}{|{\mathcal{P}}^*|-1}\sum_{A\in{\mathcal{P}}^*}H(X_{A^c}^n|X_A^n,{\textsf{L}})\label{cmi0}\\
   & = H(X_{\mathcal{M}}^n) - H(\textsf{L}) \notag\\
   &\hspace{0.5cm}- \frac{1}{|{\mathcal{P}}^*|-1} \sum_{A\in{\mathcal{P}}^*}\biggl[H(X_{{\mathcal{M}}}^n) - H(X_A^n) - H({\textsf{L}}|X_A^n)\biggr] \label{cmi1} \\
   & = n\sum_{e\in{\mathcal{E}}}{\mathbf{w}}(e)\left(1-\frac{|{\mathcal{P}}^*|}{|{\mathcal{P}}^*|-1}\right)\notag\\
   &\hspace{0.5cm}+\frac{n}{|{\mathcal{P}}^*|-1}\biggl[\sum_{e\in{\mathcal{E}}}{\mathbf{w}}(e)+\sum_{e\in{\mathcal{E}}_{{\mathcal{P}}^*}}{\mathbf{w}}(e)\biggr]- H(\textsf{L}) \notag\\
   &\hspace{0.5cm}+ \frac{1}{|{\mathcal{P}}^*|-1} \sum_{A\in{\mathcal{P}}^*} H(\textsf{L}|X_A^n) \label{cmi2}\\
   & = \frac{n}{|{\mathcal{P}}^*|-1}\sum_{e\in{\mathcal{E}}_{{\mathcal{P}}^*}}{\mathbf{w}}(e)\notag\\
   &\hspace{0.5cm} - \frac{1}{|{\mathcal{P}}^*|-1} \left[ \sum_{A\in{\mathcal{P}}^*} I(X_A^n;{\textsf{L}})-H({\textsf{L}})\right] \notag \\
   & = \frac{n}{|{\mathcal{P}}^*|-1}\left(\sum_{e\in{\mathcal{E}}_{{\mathcal{P}}^*}}{\mathbf{w}}(e)-\frac{1}{n}H({\textsf{L}})\right)\notag\\
   &\hspace{0.5cm}-\frac{1}{|{\mathcal{P}}^*|-1} \left[ \sum_{A\in{\mathcal{P}}^*} I(X_A^n;{\textsf{L}})-2H({\textsf{L}})\right] \notag \\
   & \geq \frac{n}{|{\mathcal{P}}^*|-1}\left(\sum_{e\in{\mathcal{E}}_{{\mathcal{P}}^*}}{\mathbf{w}}(e)-\frac{1}{n}H({\textsf{L}})\right), \label{cmi3}
\end{align}

where \eqref{cmi0} and \eqref{cmi1} follow from the fact that ${\textsf{L}}$ is a function of $X_{{\mathcal{M}}}^n$; \eqref{cmi2} follows from the fact that $H(X_{{\mathcal{M}}}^n)=n\sum_{e\in{\mathcal{E}}}{\mathbf{w}}(e)$ and $\sum_{A\in{\mathcal{P}}^*}H(X_A^n)=n\biggl[\sum_{e\in{\mathcal{E}}}{\mathbf{w}}(e)+\sum_{e\in{\mathcal{E}}_{{\mathcal{P}}^*}}{\mathbf{w}}(e)\biggr]$; and \eqref{cmi3} is due to Lemma~\ref{lem:mi}.

Now, consider $\textsf{L}$ to be any ${\text{CI}}_W$ so that for any $\epsilon > 0$, we have $\frac{1}{n}I(X_{\mathcal{M}}^n | \textsf{L}) < \frac{\epsilon}{(|{\mathcal{P}}^*|-1)}$ for all sufficiently large $n$. The bound in \eqref{cmi3} thus yields $\frac{1}{n}H({\textsf{L}})> \sum_{e\in{\mathcal{E}}_{{\mathcal{P}}^*}}{\mathbf{w}}(e)-\epsilon$ for all sufficiently large $n$. Hence, it follows that ${\text{CI}}_W(X_{{\mathcal{M}}}) \ge \sum_{e\in{\mathcal{E}}_{{\mathcal{P}}^*}}{\mathbf{w}}(e)$. Therefore, we obtain $CI_W(X_{{\mathcal{M}}})=\sum_{e\in{\mathcal{E}}_{{\mathcal{P}}^*}}{\mathbf{w}}(e)$.
\end{IEEEproof} 

We now prove Theorem~\ref{th:lb}.

\begin{IEEEproof}[Proof of Theorem~\ref{th:lb}]
